money_flow.intermediary: Arkansas DHS Division of Medical Services
money_flow.destination: Certified Peer Support Specialists and providers

authority_reference.effects: Authorizes DHS to establish and maintain an indigent medical care program and allows the DHS secretary to enter agreements with public and private entities to provide medical care to indigent persons and make rules for the program【684936796028014†L73-L98】.

authority_reference.citation: Ark. Code § 20-77-135 (Peer support specialist background checks)
authority_reference.effects: Prevents DHS from disqualifying or excluding an individual from the Medicaid program based solely on a non‑violent criminal conviction if the individual is a certified peer support specialist; requires due process in the certification process【977612311711223†L72-L97】.

authority_reference.citation: Ark. Code § 20‑46‑301 (Division of Aging, Adult, and Behavioral Health Services)
authority_reference.administering_body: Division of Aging, Adult, and Behavioral Health Services (DAABHS)
authority_reference.effects: Creates and empowers the Division of Aging, Adult, and Behavioral Health Services within DHS to operate mental health clinics and centers, provide mental health education programs, and lease employees to community mental health centers【884820613071200†L75-L88】.

authority_reference.citation: Ark. Code § 20‑64‑602(b)(19) (Standards for alcohol and drug abuse programs)
authority_reference.administering_body: Division of Aging, Adult, and Behavioral Health Services / Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health (OSAMH)
authority_reference.effects: Authorizes the division to develop and promulgate standards and rules for accrediting, certifying, and licensing alcohol and drug abuse prevention, treatment and rehabilitation programs【720090630275044†L160-L200】.

authority_reference.administering_body: Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health (OSAMH)
authority_reference.effects: Creates the position of Arkansas Drug Director within OSAMH; the director, appointed by the governor, coordinates alcohol and drug programs and performs financial monitoring of drug task forces【888369347257430†L74-L103】.

Empowers DHS and its divisions to promulgate rules and adopt federal requirements necessary to receive federal funding, recognizing that the department must operate within changing federal laws【12071825929807†L72-L103】.

authority_reference.citation: Peer Training and Certification page – description of the Arkansas Peer Recovery Program (APRP)
authority_reference.administering_body: Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health (OSAMH)
authority_reference.effects: OSAMH administers the Arkansas Peer Recovery Program, a three‑tier credentialing process (core, advanced, supervisor) designed to produce highly trained peer workers. The program is carried out with a DHS‑approved accrediting entity and is authorized by Ark. Code § 20‑64‑602(b)(19). Certification involves classroom education, on‑the‑job training and mentorship【702168819522465†L870-L882】.

authority_reference.citation: Arkansas Peer Advisory Committee page – description of APAC’s role
authority_reference.administering_body: Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health / Arkansas Peer Advisory Committee (APAC)
authority_reference.effects: APAC serves as a key resource for OSAMH on peer recovery matters. Members include the DHS Office of Recovery and up to 15 community stakeholders who are certified peer workers. APAC evaluates and approves the eligibility of peer recovery supervisors prior to certification testing and approves continuing education hours required for peer workers【755787514605201†L880-L888】.

authority_reference.citation: Get to Know Director Stone page – biography of OSAMH director Paula Stone
authority_reference.administering_body: Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health (OSAMH)
authority_reference.effects: Paula Stone serves as Director of OSAMH. She oversees the state’s public mental health system, the state’s forensic system, federal grant programs aimed at preventing and treating substance use disorder, and the team that leads the Arkansas State Hospital【517013002479678†L877-L889】.

authority_reference.citation: Get to Know Director Hill page – biography of Jay Hill
authority_reference.administering_body: Division of Aging, Adult, and Behavioral Health Services (DAABHS)
authority_reference.effects: Jay Hill serves as the director of DAABHS. He oversees programs that promote the health, safety and independence of older Arkansans and adults with disabilities. Hill began working at DHS at the Arkansas Health Center in 2006, became its director in 2011 and accepted his current position in 2017【56897009336872†L871-L878】.

authority_reference.citation: Get to Know Director Pitman page – biography of Elizabeth Pitman
authority_reference.effects: Elizabeth Pitman serves as Director of the Division of Medical Services for the Medicaid program. She manages Medicaid operations, including managed care programs, claims processing, contracts and the fee‑for‑service program【91964929200516†L874-L879】.

authority_reference.citation: Meet the Secretary page – biography of Janet Mann
authority_reference.effects: Janet Mann is the Secretary of DHS and also the State Medicaid Director. With over twenty years of experience in healthcare and healthcare finance, she provides executive leadership for the department and previously served as Deputy Secretary for Programs and Director of DMS【776702696406669†L865-L871】.

authority_reference.citation: Meet the Secretary page – description of Misty Eubanks’s role
authority_reference.effects: Misty Eubanks serves as Deputy Secretary for Operations and Budget. She manages DHS operations and budget and has held roles such as Chief Financial Officer, Chief Procurement Officer and Privacy Officer【776702696406669†L878-L887】.

authority_reference.citation: Meet the Secretary page – description of Melissa Weatherton’s role
authority_reference.effects: Melissa Weatherton serves as Director of Specialty Medicaid Services. She oversees specialty Medicaid programs with a focus on the Division of Developmental Disabilities Services, Division of Aging, Adult and Behavioral Health Services, and Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health【776702696406669†L891-L899】.

authority_reference.citation: News release: Arkansas Drug Director changing job (July 27, 2022)
authority_reference.effects: Kirk Lane served as Arkansas Drug Director from 2017 until August 2022. Appointed by Governor Asa Hutchinson, he coordinated statewide efforts to prevent substance abuse, launched the Arkansas Naloxone Program and led peer recovery initiatives. His resignation announcement noted that he had been at the forefront of overdose prevention and peer recovery programs【23235813013277†L853-L889】.

authority_reference.citation: ARORP article: Governor of Arkansas elects new Drug Director (Feb. 17, 2023)
authority_reference.effects: On February 17, 2023 Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders announced that Thomas Fisher, a former Department of Justice and DEA official, would serve as Arkansas’s new Drug Director. Fisher will succeed Boyce Hamlet and oversee the state’s drug policies while continuing collaboration with former Drug Director Kirk Lane【883227464789966†L75-L87】.

authority_reference.citation: Empower Behavioral Health Handbook (2026) – Peer Support section
authority_reference.effects: Sets billing codes and limits for peer support services: code H0038 UC U4 for peer support and H0038 U4 for telephonic peer support; one unit equals 15 minutes; daily maximum 8 units; annual limit 104 units without an extension of benefits; service available for members aged 18 and over and must be delivered by a Certified Peer Support Specialist【818410471609231†L1320-L1333】.

authority_reference.citation: Provider Enrollment page – instructions for enrolling as an Arkansas Medicaid provider
authority_reference.effects: The Provider Enrollment Unit manages enrollment for Arkansas Medicaid providers. Providers must complete an online application and may call (501) 376‑2211 or (800) 457‑4454 for assistance. Certain high‑risk providers are required to undergo fingerprint‑based background checks. Providers must report National Provider Identifier numbers and re‑enroll every five years【273577708421788†L998-L1053】.

authority_reference.citation: APAC page – biography of Casey Copeland, APAC chair
authority_reference.effects: Casey Copeland, a person in long‑term recovery, serves as the chair of the Arkansas Peer Advisory Committee and as Director of Recovery Services for the State of Arkansas. He plays a key role in creating, managing and rolling out peer recovery programs statewide and leads the committee that evaluates peer recovery supervisors and continuing education【755787514605201†L905-L929】.
